entry.title: Build your own API endpoint with Apollo GraphQL
entry.content:
The beginning

Nowadays to a F2Eâ€™s(aka. Front End Engineer) skills are way more complex than 3 or 4 years ago, you canâ€™t just know how to process a bunch of PSDs into html but also have to make your pages works together, especially when you are creating a Web APP.

To make an APP work weâ€™ll need the API endpoint to provide necessary data so F2E can display/manipulate them and make APP alive.
Here Iâ€™ll demonstrate of how to use GraphQL to create the endpoint, itâ€™s a bit related to backend stuff but no worries.

Preparation

  • Nodejs@^8.15.1
  • ES6 syntax knowledge
  • nodemon (optional)
  • Packages
    • apollo-server-express@^2.9.7
    • express@^4.17.1
    • faker@^4.1.0
    • graphql-tools@^4.0.6
    • morgan@^1.9.1

Initial a NPM project

Install packages and letâ€™s check the directory structures:

We have a folder named app and a folder named schemas there will be our codesâ€™ houses then.

Coding

Step one, create a server to handle http requests, we are going to use express to do this.

To use GraphQL in backend we can choose Apollo Server, it is a community-maintained open-source GraphQL server, and its example to Express is sample but for the reason of decoupling to modules we will have one apollo.js and another is server.js.

As you can see we have decoupled apollo part to apollo.js, in this file we only configure express:

  • Use an express plugin called morgan to display serverâ€™s log in terminal console.
  • Module apollo applied as a middleware to express.
  • Server listen to port 4000 and when server start display a log shows server is ready.

Codesandbox

Before we start the server lets finish apollo.js now.

Hmm, seems nothing special just import modules and export module but letâ€™s remember the context and continue discover folder schemas.

GraphQL type definition and resolvers.

In GraphQL type definition we create two custom types named User and Address and Query is the default type every typeDefs need one.

We add fields to each type and restrict its value as String or Address so we know filed can be a custom type and its value will be the custom typeâ€™s fields as an Object.

Also the filed could have arguments and be restricted.

For the default Query type we also have a field users and the value is a list of User. This filed will return users we have and could be an array of object/null or null because we donâ€™t restrict the list or User to be required which represent in code would be [User]! Or [User!].

Look at resolvers carefully isnâ€™t it an Object to you, it has a key named Query and a sub-key named users like the type we defined in typeDefs, the function of users will be the resolver for generating users data â€“ an array of objects.

Loot at the functionâ€™s parameters, the second one comes from request variables the third one comes from apollo-serverâ€™s context we pass before.

Playground

Now start server by

And using these queries to get your users.

Have fun with them!

entry.title: Applications of Intersection Observer API
entry.content:
The IntersectionObserver interface of the Intersection Observer API provides a way to asynchronously observe changes in the intersection of a target element with an ancestor element or with a top-level documentâ€™s viewport. The ancestor element or viewport is referred to as the root.

When an IntersectionObserver is created, itâ€™s configured to watch for given ratios of visibility within the root. The configuration cannot be changed once the IntersectionObserver is created, so a given observer object is only useful for watching for specific changes in degree of visibility; however, you can watch multiple target elements with the same observer.

â€“ MDN IntersectionObserver

1. Lazyload

Traditionally we are using onscroll event in window to handle lazyload, usually lazyload image source to accelerate page loading to accomplish the concept of Critical Rendering Path. Anything not visible within the â€œinitial viewâ€ we can lazy load it afterwards.

Here is the code snippet using IntersectionObserver API to lazyload <img>

Now with above snippets we can already load image source when scroll to the <picture> tag but there is an obviously FOUC(flash of unstyled content).

check this reference blog to fix it.

2. Sticky Navigation/Menu/etc.

position: sticky is available in the selectorsâ€™ container if I want a <nav> always sticky in the top of the page I need to make it as the child of <body> tag or a content container, if this is not the design create a sticky navigation and put it as the child of the container and not visible until when the fixed navigation is not visible then show the sticky navigation. Still onscroll can do this but we are using IntersectionObserver today.

Here are two example for using both

  • https://ebidel.github.io/demos/sticky-position-event.html
  • https://codepen.io/danirod/pen/preJgX

Polyfill

IE doesnâ€™t support both functions so we have polyfill for:

  • IntersectionObserver
  • position: sticky

entry.title: Integrate Frontend Build Tasks into Maven
entry.content:
Sometimes when build a maven project you also want frontend resources are built along with whole build process, here is the solution.

TL;DR

  • Apache Maven 3.3.9
  • Plugin: frontend-maven-plugin 1.6
  • A pom.xml profile (e.g. for an AEM project)
  • Build command add the profile before other profiles
  • Check console if the gulp task is run successfully

Longer version

Make sure you have the right version of maven and plugin then add the configure into your pom.xml

Command

Console

Here you can see console logs out specific version of Node and Yarn is installed but for the first time you run it the plugin will download specific version of node and yarn and install to your ${workingDirectory}/node, this is happened in the first execution section. The other two execution sections are mainly for download task dependencies and run specific task and you can see the last line of log the gulp task is running.

Done.
